New Records: Devon Conway broke Martin Guptill's 88-ball record for the fastest 50-overs World Cup century by a New Zealander, bringing his up in just 83 balls.
Rachin Ravindra became the country's youngest centurion in a global tournament at 23.
Rachin Ravindra and Devon Conway put on an unbroken 273 for the second wicket, the Blackcaps' highest partnership in the tournament's history.
Key Match Events: Devon Conway smashed 152 off 119 balls, while Rachin Ravindra scored 123 not out, leading New Zealand to a 9-wicket win.
Matt Henry took 3 for 48, dovetailing with 2 for 37 from Mitchell Santner, to keep England in check.
Joe Root's 77 was the highest score for England, but they were bowled out for 282.
Rachin Ravindra and Devon Conway's partnership began at the start of the second over, making it all the more remarkable.
Ravindra's shotmaking was crisp from the off, notably when crunching a flat six over square leg from a Mark Wood delivery that registered 148kph.
Pre-Game Insights: There were no pre-game insights provided in the article.
Post-Match Reflections: England's efforts with the bat had various jumping-off points for a score greater than the 282 for 9 they managed from 50 overs.
Joe Root's 77 stitched together a total of 282 for 9 after Tom Latham had won the toss and opted to bowl first.

For the first time in an ODI innings, all 11 batters reached double figures, yet with just one fifty-plus stand - a 70 between Root and Buttler, ending with the latter's failed attempt at guiding Henry down to third.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The defending champions looked to have reached a competitive total at the halfway stage.
The last player to manage 10 boundary-less overs against England was Kuldeep Yadav in July 2018.
New Zealand blitzed the boundary count 38 to 27, even blitzing the fastest chase of a 250-plus target in World Cup history.
The match was played at the Ahmedabad stadium, and New Zealand won by 9 wickets with 82 balls remaining.
